newsitem.title: UK: London gold in doldrums after U.S. rate rise.
newsitem.headline: London gold in doldrums after U.S. rate rise.

text.p: Gold was weaker and market sentiment soggy on Wednesday morning following Tuesday's sharp price declines on the rise in U.S. interest rates.
Bullion fixed at $346.80 per ounce, compared with $349.60 on Tuesday afternoon and a London close of $348.95/$349.95.
General selling helped depress prices as low as $346.10 in early Europe, dealers said.
But good physical offtake was cushioning gold's descent, and prices had come off the lows, they added.
So far the $346.00 level was holding, but strong support was expected at $345.30, the recent low from March 18.
Gold slid below the psychological $350 level amid options-related and speculative selling on Tuesday.
The U.S. interest rate rise of 25 basis points then depressed prices further.
"While the 0.25 percent rate hike by the Fed was fully expected by the market, it still contributed to losses in gold," brokers GNI said in a report.
"While there was some expectation of a 'buy the fact' rally, when it did not come there was general selling."
Technically gold was in the doldrums and might be headed for the February low of $336, GNI added.
Other precious metals were also weak and vulnerable to further downside tests, dealers said.
Silver was last indicated at $5.09/$5.10, down three cents and near the very bottom of its recent range.
"I'm pegging support at $5.08. But so far it looks reluctant to follow gold lower," a dealer said.
Some dealers said they would not be surprised to see a test of $5.05 and possibly $5.00 if silver came under speculative pressure again.
"The uptrend has run out of steam and the critical support at 510 cents looks threatened now," said analyst Elli Gifford.
"Prices need to recover to levels over 530 cents at least if the risk of a breakdown coming through is to reduce," Gifford said in an Investment Research of Cambridge commentary.
Platinum fixed at $372.00 an ounce, down $2.75 from the previous fixing and the lowest fix since February 21.

Palladium was also fixed lower at $144.50, versus $146.00 on Tuesday afternoon. The rare white metals had dropped sharply on Tuesday following news that strikes at Russian producer Norilsk were being postponed.
